case_name: Brij Mohan Singh v. Priya Brat Narain Sinha

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 9 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 9 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 9, 1964 of Patna High Court in Election Appeal No. 2 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Election Appeal No. 2 of 1963.

facts.text: Brij Mohan Singh is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Brij Mohan Singh and the resportdent Priya

facts.text: Priya Brat Narain Sinha is respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Brij Mohan Singh and the resportdent Priya Brat Narain Sinha were among the candidates

facts.text: Appellant and respondent contested Aurangabad Constituency seat for Bihar Legislative Assembly at General Election 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Priya Brat Narain Sinha were among the candidates who companytested the Aurangabad Constituency seat for the Bihar Legislative Assembly at the General Election held in 1962.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 21, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on February 21, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant received majority of votes and was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant received a majority of votes and was declared elected.

facts.text: Respondent Priya Brat Narain Sinha was the sitting member and was defeated.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Priya Brat Babu who was the sitting member was defeated on April 9, 1962,

facts.text: Respondent filed election petition on April 9, 1962 challenging validity of appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: he filed a petition challenging the validity of the appellants election. He prayed for a declaration that the election

facts.text: Respondent prayed for declaration that appellant's election be declared void and respondent declared duly elected from Aurangabad Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: He prayed for a declaration that the election of the appellant Brij Mohan Singh be declared void and that he  Priya Brat Narain Sinha  be declared to have been duly elected

facts.text: Respondent claimed appellant born on October 15, 1937 and under 25 years on nomination date, disqualified under Art. 137 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: That the appellant was born on October 15, 1937 and was thus under 25 years of age on the date of filing the numberination papers and therefore disqualified under Art. 137

facts.text: Respondent claimed appellant held subsisting contracts under Bihar Government in personal capacity, disqualified under s.7d Representation of the People Act.

anchor.surface_text: That he held subsisting companytracts under the Bihar Government in his individual and personal capacity and was thus disqualified under s. 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act

facts.text: Respondent claimed appellant and his party-men responsible for publication and distribution of leaflets containing false insinuations against respondent's personal character.

anchor.surface_text: That the appellant, and with his companysent, his party-men Rameshwar Prasad Singh and others  whose names are mentioned  were directly responsible for publication and distribution of companyies of leaflets companytaining direct insinuations

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the petition after considering evidence, holding no grounds established.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held on a companysideration of the oral and documentary evidence produced before it that numbere of these or the other grounds on which the validity of the election was challenged had been established.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside Election Tribunal's judgment and order, and set aside appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Tribunal dismissed the petition. On appeal, the High Court of Judicature at Patna set aside the judgment and order of the Election Tribunal and made an order setting aside the election

facts.text: High Court refused respondent's prayer to be declared duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: of the appellant Brij Mohan Singh to the Bihar Legislative Assembly. The High Court however refused the respondents prayer to be declared duly elected.

facts.text: Present appeal preferred on certificate granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(b) Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the present appeal has been preferred on a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Tribunal that appellant did not hold contract under Government in personal capacity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the Election Tribunal that the allegation that the appellant held a companytract under the Government in his personal capacity had number been established.

facts.text: High Court held appellant below 25 years on date of filing nomination, not qualified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant was below the age of 25 years on the date of filing the numberination and was therefore number qualified to be a candidate

facts.text: High Court held appellant published leaflet Ex.10 containing attacks on respondent's personal character, guilty of corrupt practice u/s 123(4) RP Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the appellant had published a leaflet Ex. 10 companytaining attacks upon the personal character of the respondent and was thus guilty of a companyrupt practice within the meaning of s. 123 4  of the Representation

facts.text: Supreme Court concluded not proved that appellant committed corrupt practice or below 25 on nomination date.

anchor.surface_text: After companysidering the evidence his Lordship companycluded that it was number proved that the appellant had companymitted any companyrupt practice or that he was below twenty- five years on the date of filing of numberination papers.

facts.text: Hathchitha is an official record maintained by illiterate Chowkidar.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether an entry made in an official record maintained by an illiterate public servant, by some one else at his request is relevant under s. 35 of the Evidence Act

facts.text: Supreme Court held hathchitha genuine, maintained by Chowkidar for births 1934-1936.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the physical appearance on the hathchitha and the entries made therein, the evidence of the Chowkidar and the circumstances under which this document was ultimately produced before the Tribunal we are inclined to agree ... that this is a genuine document which was maintained by the Chowkidar ... for numbering the births in his Ilaka during the years 1934 to 1936.

facts.text: Entry in hathchitha shows birth of son to Sarjoo Singh on October 15, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The entry therein showing the birth of a son to Sarjoo Singh on October 15, 1935 can however be of numberassistance to the appellant

facts.text: Chowkidar did not make the entry himself, got someone else to do it.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, however, the Chowkidar himself did number make it.

facts.text: Supreme Court held entry not admissible under s.35 Evidence Act because made by someone else for illiterate Chowkidar.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the High Court is right in holding that the entry made in an official record maintained by the illiterate Chowkidar, by somebody else at his request does number companye within s. 35 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the physical appearance on the hathchitha and the entries made therein, the evidence of the Chowkidar and the circumstances under which this document was ultimately produced before the Tribunal we are inclined to agree ... that this is a genuine document which was maintained by the Chowkidar ...

arguments.claim: When an illiterate public servant gets an entry made by somebody else, it should be treated as an entry made by the public servant himself under s. 35 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Agarwal tried to convince us that when an illiterate public servant is unable to make an entry himself and he gets the entry made by somebody else this should be treated as an entry made by the public servant.

arguments.court_reasoning: Probability of accuracy reduced when illiterate public servant depends on another; does not come within s.35

arguments.claim: The omission of Chowkidar to produce document and warrant of arrest were pre-arranged to create atmosphere for acceptance as genuine

anchor.surface_text: We are number impressed by the argument of Mr. Sarjoo Prasad that the omission of the Chowkidar to produce the document in obedience to the summons and the issue of warrant of arrest to secure its production were all pre- arranged to create an atmosphere for the acceptance of the document as genuine.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s that when an illiterate public servant is unable to make an entry himself and he gets the entry made by somebody else this should be treated as an e

arguments.court_reasoning: not impressed; unlikely lawyers would risk warrant

arguments.claim: Entry in hathchitha made by somebody else at request of illiterate Chowkidar does not come within s. 35 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the High Court is right in holding that the entry made in an official record maintained by the illiterate Chowkidar, by somebody else at his request does number companye within s. 35 of the Evidence Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.35 relevancy based on high probability of truth when made by public servant himself; reduced for illiterate relying on others

holdings.text: An entry made in an official record maintained by an illiterate Chowkidar, by somebody else at his request, does not come within s. 35 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the High Court is right in holding that the entry made in an official record maintained by the illiterate Chowkidar, by somebody else at his request does number companye within s. 35 of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 35 relevancy premised on high probability of accuracy from public servant making entry himself; probability diminishes substantially for illiterate servant depending on others.
